body: Looks like parallel composite reader fix is addressed by @Chand2048 in https://github.com/apache/lucenenet/pull/102, I will close this and reopen only with TestIndexWriterExceptions fix.
@laimis what do you make of @Chand2048 's comment about this test not existing in the original Java code?

oh yeah, thanks for pointing that out @synhershko. I see the test in Lucene, it is this: https://github.com/apache/lucene-solr/blob/lucene_solr_4_8_0/lucene/core/src/test/org/apache/lucene/index/TestParallelCompositeReader.java#L392
@synhershko done!
This is the squashed and rebased version.
Moved to new branch and cleaned up.
Rebased and removed the attempt to use AggregateException. This caused problems.
Merged. We should probably add a LUCENE TODO to tackle this later since we are swallowing the original exception

@Chand2048 this is exactly how this is being done in Apache Lucene - see https://github.com/apache/lucene-solr/blob/lucene_solr_4_8_0/lucene/core/src/test/org/apache/lucene/index/TestSnapshotDeletionPolicy.java#L66

So we either missed a clean-up procedure that's being done there, or there's something else that we do differently. Either way, I'd like to avoid fixing the test - we may be covering up another problem.

You are correct. Unfortunately my local copy of the java source does not have the global list. It actually puts the snapshots into the SnapshotDeletionPolicy instance passed into the function. I will get my source to the correct version and take a look again. Sorry for the confusion.
I'll handle this in a few days, won't merge for now

I'm holding off with merging this because I don't really like the way `WeakIdentityMap` is implemented and I'd like to review it a bit before deciding what to do with it. Hopefully I'll get to it in the next few days.
I want to review this properly and see what our options are for trusted LRU implementations, not going to merge for now until we get it right for sure.

Ok just reviewed it - this class has only 2 usages and the fix looks legit enough...

I moved class using it to the TestFramework project; the other only usage warrant making `WeakIdentityMap` internal but we'll get to it when we are done by setting up `InternalsVisibleTo` properly for the test projects

Sounds good, @synhershko. I figured it was safe to ignore as it had Lucene Net TODO comment in it to go back and fix it once all the required codecs are ported. I will open another PR with just "snapshots" changes which you can pull in.

Never mind, I see that you merged it into the master.

@synhershko question for you about that test marked as ignored. It looks like Pulsing41PostingsFormat has been ported and compiles. Are we OK to reference Codecs project from core tests at this stage? Or should we wait until all the tests for codecs have been included and compiling. I see the Codec test files are checked in but they are not included in the project.
Yes, but if you can do some work on the Codec tests that will be great
Yes, but if you can do some work on the Codec tests that will be great
Merged, but can you please confirm those tests are now in-line with the Java one?

@synhershko I can confirm that they are. What I was doing was run Java version side by side to make sure the tests did not rely on the instance variables in any way. In Lucene, again they benefit from the test runner initializing instance variables on each test run. In .NET that does not happen and we end up getting failures like these instead: http://teamcity.codebetter.com/viewLog.html?buildId=184897&tab=buildResultsDiv&buildTypeId=LuceneNet_Core#testNameId-4229341108728890812
Thanks! Looks fine.
Thanks @laimis -- can you do said review?
@synhershko yup, found several places and will get them in through the next commits.

Is there a reason to have that marker interface public and not kept private?

While I'd assume there are more places like this, I wonder if we can assume they are all internal and avoid exposing this interface?
Thanks. We are not actively maintaining the 3.x branch as we put all our efforts in having a 4.x release soon. I'll be keeping this around for a reference.
@synhershko great point, I will adjust, there is no need for it to be public.
Done.

Good catch, will merge now

Can you evaluate if we still need that non-generic class?

@synhershko took a look, it seems like we need it because there are places using this without explicit specification of generic type T to match what Lucene is doing (where it declares it as FieldComparator<?>).

The same problem might exist in MMapDirectory and NIOFSDirectory but I haven't been able to verify them yet. Figured to push this out first, get confirmation on TC in addition to my local tests that look good, and then verify if those two are misbehaving the same way.
Ran tests for MMapDirectory / NIOFSDirectory and looks like those open with sharemode set to read / write / delete. Adjusted the code in Lucene.Net to match the same behavior.

I would go ahead and fix all those occurrences, at least the ones that in the matching Java code are expected not to throw. Note in `Lucene.Net.Support.BitSetSupport` we have several other extension methods (SafeSet etc), all provide support around BitArray usage to mimic Java's BitSet API.

The reason why I think we should make sure all calls to BitArray is because otherwise we are sure our port is wrong (throws while the Java code does not), and even though we have randomized tests we are still not necessarily covering all code paths (or haven't yet had enough test runs).
Awesome work, thanks. Pushing this now and let's see if TC confirms.
Hold off on merging this one just yet, the failing test got fixed with this, but now new failures are appearing in the related code. Investigating...

It looks like those other tests were failing because they were modified in Lucene.Net to work around the bug, ie tests were adjusted to pass while leaving the bug in place.

Corrected the tests to match Lucene. Here is the Lucene tests, starting with the first line that was made to match:

https://github.com/apache/lucene-solr/blob/lucene_solr_4_8_0/lucene/core/src/test/org/apache/lucene/index/TestTermVectorsWriter.java#L129

Good catch

2 things come to mind:
1. `OffsetGap_Renamed` and such other `_Renamed` instances need to be, well, renamed and have that suffix dropped. It's the converter doings, and it just makes the code base looks bad
2. I'm sure there are more such places, e.g. nullables that were ported as value types and somewhere in the code are compared to null, indicating they should indeed be nullables. R# should highlight those comparisons, but we need to search for them and inspect one by one.

@synhershko agreed on _Renamed. I have been reluctant to touch those so as to keep the changes focused on the bug fix bug can start fixing those as I go.

Re: nullables, I looked at the compiler warnings for more of these spots and there were 3-4 more. Trying to nail down the remaining failing tests and then can grab those too if no one gets to it first. They did seem to be in the spots that are not very likely to be triggered.
Oh and there is one method that is a test in Lucene but [Test] attribute was missed in the conversion process it seems.
@synhershko I am pushing the debug.asserts with side effects into this PR and then will wait for you to discuss what to do here (merge the changes, come up with some other "assert" method, etc).
What I have here should be all that show up in unit test failures. Will do another pass in couple days to see if there are more spots like these in the code base.
All looks good, I don't see anything to discuss here really. Will merge now.
Also removed LongRunningTest or Ignore attributes on the tests that used to fail because of this before.
Can you rebase please? :)
@synhershko can you check now? If it is too messy I can reopen a different PR, ot sure if I did this right

Good catch, I'll merge now.

For the record, `DateTime.UtcNow.Ticks` is a closer equivalent to `System.currentTimeMillis` but for the purpose of this change your change is good enough. Thanks.
@synhershko oh yeah, you are right, I will keep that in mind.

Great catch! However, I would just replace the lock with ReaderWriterLockSlim and EnterReadLock.
this might be performance critical section.

while the FileStream seek is moving to another pointer, another thread will not read the correct position.
The correct way to do it is by async

take a look:
https://github.com/eladmarg/lucene.net/commit/7ea8f870ee3b3e9fb3512dee0fbee67b69a6da86

Thanks @laimis 

@eladmarg my first priority is to get all tests green and be ready to get a release out the door. There are differences between .NET non-blocking IO and Java.nio -- and the move to NIO isn't smooth. Merged this one, and will be happy to get a separate PR with this change.

@synhershko , Thanks.
I think this solution also won't solve the problem.
instead, the solution should be many FileStream objects, which require a big refactor.

However, I agree that first priority is to get a stable release and only then, performance optimization
Looks like running this change in TC still has that test failing.  I will continue to dig in the separate branch to see if I can reproduce it.
Looks good - let's do this!

Great job on this so far. I had a lot of problems getting ICU4NET properly integrated and running, so this alone is a fine start. Not that I have any say, but I'd vote for continuing with this plan rather than coming up with something else for a BreakIterator implementation.

This is a bit tricky. icu4net doesn't seem to be that active (~40 commits in 4 years, last one >6 months ago), and the 32bit stuff is quite problematic. And I'd rather avoid maintaining yet another project.

On the other hand, there's no point in reinventing the wheel - so long as we can confirm the validity and quality of that project.

Take a look at icu4j - that's a Java implementation Lucene uses quiet a bit on itself. Maybe that is just a few classes that we can port over from there and the icu4net project?

I had similar concerns to your @synhershko yet at the same time felt like it was the best option for us. Some loose thoughts:
- We all want to see some progress with Lucene.Net port and going to port icu4j feels like a roadblock to that initiate. I better use icu4net and make headway with the Lucene port than go onto another project port at this stage. Perhaps live with icu4net for as long as we can but keep on thinking what it will be replaced with down the road?
- Just from taking a very raw look at the icu4j and BreakIterator for instance, it does not feel like it is a straightforward port. I could be wrong though. Also not sure if we can do that from the licensing perspective, all of their classes have comment with IBM copyright. Have no clue about those type of things (see example here: http://source.icu-project.org/repos/icu/icu4j/trunk/main/classes/core/src/com/ibm/icu/text/BreakIterator.java)
- icu4net is not active, true, but it is just a wrapper around a very active ICU4C library. I was able to take ICU4NET, compile it, etc. So we could fork that project and create our own nuget packages and wrapper classes if we wanted to. Also that includes building 64 bit version of ICU4NET by packaging 64 bit version ICU4C libs. None of this I have experience with, so it is a bit of unknown.
- The best part of ICU4C is that the classes it exposes, so far at least, have been a perfect match for Analysis at the API level. Porting CharArrayIterator was straightforward. I started porting SegmentingTokenizerBase in Utils just to see if I run into any issues, and again from the API perspective did not run into anything, it was straightforward to get to the point where it compiles (tests are failing, will figure out why :) ).

It just feels like for the sake of making progress ICU4NET is the way to go. It allows us to port Lucene code and then we can yank ICU4NET out once we feel like we have a good alternative for it.

What do you think?

While you consider I am continuing to figure out what to do with ICU4NET on CI machine. It depends on init.ps1 script to be run but nuget restore has a bug where it does not do that (http://jeffhandley.com/archive/2013/12/09/nuget-package-restore-misconceptions.aspx, search for "init.ps1" paragraph)

And @jpsullivan thanks for your input, appreciated. We don't have a lot of people around this so it is good to hear the opinion of others and have someone review the code, etc.
@synhershko removed the "buggy breakiterator" code, looks good from the tests.

Hi, thanks for submitting this.

The code in question isn't being maintained any more - it is part of a previous release and will be replaced soon with a newer version (pending to be ported from Java).

I will keep this open until we have finished porting.

Thank you again for your effort.

NoP, 

Thank you very much to you and other contributors for lucene.net :)

Regards
I had sometime to port some more code and got through SegmetingTokenizerBase and its tests. Since it builds on top of the CharArrayIterator stuff I went ahead and added it to this PR.
Sorry, got caught up in other stuff. So was this merged? I'm not quite sure what happened here :)

@synhershko yeah I went ahead and merged it to continue with the porting as this was a building block on some of the next ports I was doing. I waited a bit longer but after not hearing back just went with it.

Right now looking at the CharArrayMap / CharArraySet classes that appear to be used frequently in analysis.
Looks good, thanks!
Looks good, thanks!
@EMaher hey, merging this broke compilation (should have tried it locally first!). Can you please have a look?

It's probably failing for the interpolated string (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn961160.aspx) on https://github.com/apache/lucenenet/commit/e218ff63d0b22cbe39543986f0382f241cf47c24#diff-343b91381036b34a5e84eebc117858d8R241 

Visual Studio 2015 is using Roslyn for compilation (and usage of C#6). TC probably using the old compiler and cant use the C#6 features.

Enable the Roslyn compiler on the TC can probably be done with the Microsoft.CodeDom.Providers.DotNetCompilerPlatform/Microsoft.Net.Compilers nuget-package or the codebase should only use earlier C# specification.

It is the string interpretation causing the build to fail.  My apologies.  https://github.com/apache/lucenenet/pull/164 removes the use of the C# 6 features.  I'll make sure to avoid until C# 6 features until the CI build is ready for them.
Merged, thanks!
@EMaher
Sorry. I did this on the wrong branch.
Looks good, thanks!
Thanks!
Created PR on wrong branch.
Thanks! I've made a comment on the Exception type used

Looks great, thanks!

I add a few comments around `TestIndexWriterWithThreads`, it's not a trivial test and it's worth checking on our CI whether or not it fails before and after your changes. If it fails, it probably fails sporadically.

There is a high risk of introducing thread safety issues here, so I'd want us to cover our bases.

Let's compare the code in this test to the Java version and make sure we are preserving the same behavior. Once we know we do, let's run the tests many times, and strengthen them where possible, to make sure this is air tight.

WDYT?

Thanks for the tip , I made the change regarding the InvalidOperationException and also I had to rename a file path inside Lucene.Net.Codecs.Tests.csproj because files names are case sensitive in Linux and build wont pass without making this change.
OK.  Suggested changes have been made.  I also verified that passing tests continue to pass, especially the ones that used to use AtomicReference.
Thanks!
Thanks, merged. On your next PR, please work on a branch, it is an ill practice in git to merge from someone else's master.
Thanks, that make sense, I will follow your suggestion next time :)
Thanks!

Merged, thanks!

(1) might have found a bug - you didn't change local vars in some occasions so I had commented in some of them, (2) please document all test API changes that diverge from the Java code in the appropriate places, so we don't chase after them in the future or override them by mistake.

Looks good, let's work on getting this in. This PR currently breaks sub-projects, as the API change hasn't been propogated there and to their tests. Can you run the entire solution and make sure this API change is brought all over?
